newsitem.title: BRAZIL: BCP to invest 600 mln reais in Sao Paulo B Band.
newsitem.headline: BCP to invest 600 mln reais in Sao Paulo B Band.

text.p: An international consortium that won the concession to run cellular B Band services in metropolitan Sao Paulo will invest between 500-600 million reais to launch the service, the head of the group said.

Carlos Alberto Vieira, head of the BCP SA group of U.S. operator BellSouth Corp, Brazil's Banco Safra, media group Estado de Sao Paulo and supplier Splice do Brasil, said the service would start up in a year with 400,000 lines.
Roberto Peon, BellSouth Latin America president, said Sao Paulo was worth the 2.647 billion reais offered by the consortium for the concession.
"The Sao Paulo market warrants this kind of investment. It's one of the biggest investments in the world, but Sao Paulo is one of the most important cities in the world," he said.
Peon added that the waiting list for cellular telephone lines in South America's biggest city was believed to be anything between 800,000 and one million people.
"We hope to get a good percentage of that," he said.
The B Band service will use TDMA, or Time Division Multiple Access, technology from Canadian supplier Nortel.
Banco Safra and BellSouth each have a 46 percent share in the venture with the rest split between Splice and the Estado de Sao Paulo group.
Safra and BellSouth are already partners in a cellular telephone service in Israel.
The BCP group's basket of proposed rates was, at 82.42 reais, only 2.0 reais cheaper than that already offered by state-run Telesp, and the highest proposed by bidders for the B Band service.
